thread.title: Maryland Gov. Martin O’Malley preparing for 2016 presidential run
thread.title_full: Maryland Gov. Martin O’Malley preparing for 2016 presidential run - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Maryland Gov. Martin O’Malley preparing for 2016 presidential run
text:
Handout/Getty Images Maryland Gov. Martin O' Malley said he would make a good President 'for these times especially.' Maryland Gov. Martin O’Malley — who’s made little secret of the fact he’s considering a 2016 White House bid — suggested over the weekend that he won’t wait to see whether Hillary Clinton enters the race to launch his own campaign.
O’Malley, a popular blue-state Democrat with little national visibility, told the Washington Post Saturday that he has been meeting with policy experts, on both domestic and international issues, to develop a platform that would provide a “better way forward for our country.”
O’Malley, 51, added that he felt he would be a good President, “for these times especially.”
In making his most direct comments to date regarding a potential 2016 bid, the Maryland pol also addressed how his own consideration of a run may intersect with Hillary Clinton’s plans.
Sean Gardner/Getty Images Former Seceratary of State Hillary Clinton would be the odds-on favorite for the Democratic presidential nomination if she runs. “I have a great deal of respect for Hillary Clinton,” O’Malley said . “But for my own part, I have a responsibility to prepare and to address the things that I feel a responsibility to address.”
“To squander this important period of preparation because of horse-race concerns and handicapping concerns is just not a very productive use of energy,” he added , suggesting he won’t wait for Clinton to made a decision before he makes his own. “Right now, I’m going to keep doing what I’m doing — the thought work and the preparation work.”
Nevertheless, O’Malley wouldn’t say whether he had created a timeline for his decision and insiders told The Post he would probably skip a 2016 run if Clinton did decide to launch her own bid, out of loyalty to her.
Washington Post/Getty Images Former President Bill Clinton and Maryland Gov. Martin O' Malley share a moment at an event for Maryland Sen. Barbara Mikulski. The two-term governor, however, would face an uphill battle for the nomination whether Clinton runs or not. According to a recent Washington Post-ABC News poll, Clinton received the support of 73% of likely Democratic and Democratic-leaning independents in a hypothetical race for the party’s presidential nomination.
Vice President Joe Biden received 12%, while Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren received 8%. O’Malley did not register any support in the poll.
A separate Quinnipiac poll from January showed Clinton getting the support of 65% of likely Democratic voters. Biden followed with 8%, New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo got 3% and O’Malley got 1%.
